BE11:13am

President Trump had been outspoken on his views of the deal. The recent appointments of Mike Pompeo as Sec. of State and John Bolton as National Security Advisor have been widely seen as a prelude to a more overtly hawkish policy position. Oil prices have certainly come to discount some political risk although the exact quantum is almost impossible to fully identify and the source (e.g. Venezuela and Libya as well as Iran) even more difficult to parse. That being said the presence of political risk in oil prices is 'situation normal' and we'd argue the past 2-3 years where it has not obviously been an influence are the outlier.

DRichi Isn't it as simple as Oil is now likely to go over $80 per barrel, and if India/China join in the sanctions could go much higher

("the deal" being JCPOA, obv.)

BE11:13am

Extensive market focus has fallen on the 1m-1.5mbd fall in Iranian oil production over the 2012-2015 period of coordinated US and EU sanctions. We are sceptical that this change will have the same effect since the US is now acting alone. That said, the global reach of the US should not be under-estimated, and company concerns of running afoul of sanctions are very real. As such a material decline in Iranian oil production may not be the immediate result but a significant obstacle to further expansion seems a likely outcome. Iran had been targeting ~1Mb/d of new capacity by the early 2020s and the chances of sufficient foreign capital and knowhow being available to support this goal now seems highly unlikely.

BE11:14am

OPEC/NOPEC restraint, strong demand growth and the prospect of slowing non-OPEC supply growth (ex-US) has seen oil prices recover and rise past our estimated LT incentive price. The rising importance of political risk is actually evidence of stronger underlying fundamentals. Constraints on an important source of new capacity should concern the market but prices have so far focussed on the front of the futures curve.

BE11:20am

The consequence of the US decision is that the Airbus licences to sell passenger jets to Iran will be revoked: Airbus needs a US licence to sell the aircraft to Iran, because the aircraft contain more than 10% US content. Two licences were granted in 2016. It is unclear whether Airbus will manage to deliver an additional A330-200 within the next six months, but the volumes most at risk are the 28 A330-900neo and the 16 A350-1000 aircraft, since these are difficult to reallocate. In comparison, reallocating 32 A320neo and 7A321ceo aircraft should not be an issue. The A330-900neo is not selling well, with Airbus having recently decided to lower the annual output from 60 to 50. As for the A350-1000, it could be under pressure with 167 outstanding orders, but the risk is that Etihad also might revise down its order for 22 aircraft, hence c. 22% of the A350-1000 order book is now potentially at risk.

Shinshin Because if not the slots just get moved over to toerh buyers, surely ? There's a waiting list for all those models
BE11:20am

BE11:21am

The Iran Air order represents only 1.4% of the total order book of 7,189 aircraft at Q1. However, it is possible these aircraft represent a larger proportion of near-term deliveries. 100 aircraft would be ~4% of our forecast for Airbus deliveries over the next three years. We would anticipate few issues with reallocating the 46 single aisle aircraft included in the order. Reallocating the 36 A330s and 16 A350s could be more challenging in the short-term, though we would not expect a change to production rates on the back of this news, following the recent cut to A330 rates.

We don't know whether the Iranian business will be impacted or not, but it seems plausible that the risks to the business have increased. Peugeot is more exposed on this issue than other European OEMs. We continue to believe that the extrapolation of current very high Peugeot EBIT margins in Peugeot valuations is overly optimistic. On any other scenario, the shares look very expensive relative to history, on peak margins. Peugeot sentiment seems very vulnerable to any EBIT downgrade risks. Remain Underweight.

The company has until now barely put a foot wrong since Roger Whiteside took over as CEO, in our view, and has deservedly seen its PE rating rise to a material premium to many Leisure and Retail peers. In light of the guidance cut in today’s statement, we believe there is a significant risk of a de-rating, with the shares currently down 15% today. We commented in our initiation of coverage “What’s baked in”, 20th November 2017 that in our base case, the company deserved to maintain its premium PE rating. However, our scenario analysis illustrated there was an asymmetric risk to the downside should the company disappoint

BE11:34am

Not all of the weakness is attributed to weather. We believe this is important, as a weather related downgrade could be more easily stripped out as a “PE of 1x event”. Management highlighted the adverse weather conditions over March and April, with snow oscillating with heat waves (heat waves also being bad for trading). There might have been a 1% impact from “Beast from the East” itself. However, management also noted that transactions were down even outside adverse weather weeks. High Street malaise is also not the full explanation – management noted that transactions were similarly impacted across their portfolio irrespective of their exposure to shopping malls. This has led management to believe that there is a broader macro explanation, such as weak consumer confidence or declining consumer credit growth, which is currently impacting.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

As management highlighted in their response to our question (on the weather impact, and key reasons for LFL weakness), it is impossible for them to isolate the reasons for weak LFL specifically in the buckets of bad weather, heightened competition, low consumer confidence, high street malaise, or weaker menu innovation. We note that McDonalds reported Q1 2018 earnings on April 30 with the following statement: “Comp sale for International Lead segment increased 7.8% for the quarter, reflecting positive results across all markets, primarily UK and Germany.” This, along with robust trading at Wetherspoon (LFLs of 4% in Q3, adjusted for Bank holiday timing) would suggest that not all companies are seeing weakness in trading.

Weather conditions were clearly unhelpful in March/April but
management’s newly cautious rhetoric is the real surprise this
morning and we’re taking the hint with our forecasts and rating.
Footfall has been weak even leaving aside the weather conditions
and management is not convinced that things will improve in the
near term. There are no changes to the company’s wider
strategy, and rightly so, but we have never been especially
relaxed with the high teen multiple and the “safe haven” status
that this implied of Greggs. That halo has now slipped and whilst
turning negative after the shares have fallen 15% may appear to
be ambulance-chasing, the shares still trade on nearly 17x PE
and that for us is too high.

A sharp rise in the shares of Virgin Money last week ahead of CYBG’s £1.6bn takeover approach is being scrutinised by the UK’s financial markets watchdog.

The Financial Conduct Authority is examining last week’s 15 per cent jump in the value of Virgin Money’s shares, which saw them rise from 271p on Friday, April 27, to close at 312.4p on Friday, May 4.

This is a large enough increase to register on the radar of the FCA, the main defender in the UK against market abuse and insider trading.

Read this morning that "mass cigars" are the best performing bit ... which I think means cheap cigars, rather than cigars you smoke in church. Here's Jefferies to summarise where we are.

BE11:46am

With the market expecting 1H18 delivery to be weak, we always felt that unless there was a significant beat (we got a beat but not significant) this update was never going to be one for building conviction in full-year delivery, which still requires 2H18 organic EPS growth of 9% to hit the bottom end of the model. Despite this, with a number of areas of encouragement for the market to hang its hat on, such as volume delivery in the context of peers, continued commitment to its model, further progress with its vapour business, and the decision to sell off non-strategic assets for up to £2bn over the next 12-24 months, the stock should outperform today.

Pharma @Mouselet, I think domestic politics pretty much explains what happened in the UK in the 70s. If you had a British Leyland car, you would not have been astonished to find they were not an export success.
BE11:46am

To like: 1) Cigarette volume performance in 1H18 of -2.1% vs. an industry volume footprint of -5.7% (-4.5% ex Japan) shows the company has maintained positive share trends from the back half of FY17 (for context JT and PM cigarette performance over the same period was -4.9% and -3.6% respectively). 2) Further development of skew to growth brands (now at 49.1% of net revenue vs. 47.6% at year end and 45.3% PY). 3) Further rollout of MyBlu. We are particularly optimistic around the prospects of MyBlu+, which should support acceleration in top line in 2H18. 4) Cash conversion levels remain over 90% (key metric of its model, which targets sustainable returns and a 10% dividend growth commitment). 5) The decision to sell further non-strategic assets for up to £2bn over the next 12-24 months. While helping to release value and further supporting the business simplification process, as well as provide funds for investment, it also may make Imperial more attractive for a potential suitor (it would not have to take on underperforming assets that it doesn't want).

Flaneur (@Sails - based NWUK - but could be happening in Ireland, dont know)
11:46 am
BE11:46am

Not to like: 1) Implied price/mix of 0%. With the company saying it needs to deliver pricing of between 4%-5% for the year to deliver on its model this could cause concern and means 8% is needed in 2H18. What we would flag, however, is IP payments in vapour were responsible for around 1%, the company said price/mix in 2Q18 was around 4%, and comps get much easier into 2H18. 2) Margin pressures are sizeable. This is not unique to Imperial at the moment but may cause its investor base concern more given its commitment to sustainable returns.
